The Buffalo sentence works in English because our grammar allows for the relative pronoun "that" to be dropped and the verb to be unconjugated. A language like Polish wouldn't let it work. It'd be something like

Buffala Buffalu, który buffala Buffalu buffalowają, buffalowają buffala Buffalu

buffala = plural for bison/buffalos
Buffalu = from the city of Buffalo
buffalowają = verb, "to buffalo" conjugated for 3rd person plural
który = relative pronoun ("that" in English)

(3:00) Here's where the Germanic rule of always requiring compound nouns are great:
- "Police help dogbitevictim" is the police helping a victim of a dogbite
- "Police help dog bite victim" can only mean the police helping the dog to bite a victim
"Police helpdog bite victim" and "Police help dog bitevictim" doesn't make sense, but "Police help dogbitten victim" does.

I disagree with the coffee mug conclusion. When you're selling something obviously you want to sell it for more than its worth to make a profit. If not you may as well keep it. When you're buying something you want to buy it for less than its worth, possibly to sell it for more later.  Asking someone how much they would charge / pay for something isnt asking them how much they think its worth but rather how much profit they think they can make from it.

Tmesis seems to be an expansion on infixes, which linguistically refers to an affix inserted within a word's stem. English tends to add intensifiers rather than anything of meaning into words, while more Native American languages, like Inuit, apply them more frequently (which is why people think that the Inuit have several different words for snow, when in actuality people may be mistaking the infix as a part of the stem/root)

The loss aversion experiment is flawed. Attempt it again with something of a known value and you will see a similar outcome. One of the most basic macroeconomic principles is that you don't make a purchase unless the thing you are purchasing is worth MORE to you than the amount you paid. As a seller, the thing you are selling must be worth LESS to you than what you are getting in return.

Try the experiment with a 100 dollar bill. The seller would have to sell it for MORE than 100 to make it worth their time/effort. The buyer would want to pay LESS than 100 for it to make it worth their time/effort. The question of how much more/less depends on several factors one of which is the amount of time/effort is required to make the transaction.

How much would you sell a 100 bill for? What if the person was right there and had the cash ready for the exchange? What if you had to drive to another nearby city to make the exchange? Why did the value of a universally known good just change? Shouldn't it have been worth EXACTLY 100 dollars the entire time?

I would notice that I said a word incorrectly before I got to the other word, and I would (without being able to prevent myself) switch the sounds unintentionally. Having "and" five times in a row does not a sentence make. At the very least, you need a subject (noun) and a verb to make a sentence, and "and" is only a conjunction. It pairs words or sentences together. The word "buffalo" is a noun and a verb, so it fills the all needs of a sentence all by itself.

So no, you could not create a coherent sentence with just the word "and", but you can with just the word "buffalo", because it works as multiple parts of speech.

I learned about tmesis from my AP Latin class where we translated Vergil's Aeneid. The cool thing about the Latin language is that "word order matters not" (AKA, Yoda's favorite language). So Roman poets could literally use the words to describe what was happening. The one that I particularly remember was a part in book where "Neptune peeked over the surface of the water." In Latin, "surface" and "water" surrounded "Neptune peeked". So it looked like "surface Neptune peeked (over) (the) water".

The stone den was damp. He asked his servants to wipe it.
After the stone den was wiped, he tried to eat those ten lions.
When he ate, he realized that these ten lions were in fact ten stone lion corpses.
Try to explain this matter.

In English:
« Lion-Eating Poet in the Stone Den »
In a stone den was a poet called Shi, who was a lion addict, and had resolved to eat ten lions.
He often went to the market to look for lions.
At ten o'clock, ten lions had just arrived at the market.
At that time, Shi had just arrived at the market.
He saw those ten lions, and using his trusty arrows, caused the ten lions to die.
He brought the corpses of the ten lions to the stone den.

In characters:

《施氏食獅史》
石室詩士施氏，嗜獅，誓食十獅。
氏時時適市視獅。
十時，適十獅適市。
是時，適施氏適市。
氏視是十獅，恃矢勢，使是十獅逝世。
氏拾是十獅屍，適石室。
石室濕，氏使侍拭石室。
石室拭，氏始試食是十獅。
食時，始識是十獅屍，實十石獅屍。
試釋是事。

vögeln = have sex, Putze = cleaning lady / Vögel = birds, putzen = to clean

syntactic ambiguity is what happens when the reader misinterprets the punctuation, or the writer messes up the proper punctuation. So, syntactic ambiguity is totally avoidable in all cases by either understanding/learning properly placed punctuation notifications (commas, dashes, quotations etc.) OR by the writer/editor properly placing these punctuation notifications.

ex. "police help dog-bite-victim" OR "police help: dog bite victim" is more understandable than "police help dog bite victim"

Consider this.  A hunter has caught a bird from a bush, which takes measurable effort, he then sees two birds in a bush which he knows he can catch but he'd have to release his current bird in order to catch these two. For a hunter gatherer, the energy required to catch 2 additional birds will not equal the the one bird already caught. Energy expenditure versus the energy gained.

I'm not saying your wrong, but the saying comes from a hunter gatherer perspective. Not literary intellectualism.
